author: pietjepuk
content:
While we're giving out opinions, I would definitely _not_ like such a model. This server is nice and focused, which makes it somewhat easy to follow even if you're not having Discord open 24/7. I understand the desire for random conversations, or even an off-topic channel, but I honestly mostly see downsides for people working on R&D or those that want to keep track of such efforts.

And I agree with Micah that allowing more off-topic discussions even in some channels will lead to more noise overall (we certainly have seen so here in the past). I'm afraid that that in turn will lead to people actually working on R&D to lose track of discussions and/or move somewhere else like private chats.

author: potuz
content:
<@301186049323958275> 
> It has been discussed, and some of us have been trying to get a bit of an unofficial commitment from the core devs about whether they would write code against and/or support a fork that wiped out censors after the fact.
Interesting, do you see a clear line about this? I can imagine myself losing my position at prysm over this. Luckily the team seems to be always on the same side. But this particular issue I think it will be dividing

author: sky.cactus
content: I would like a credible commitment from various core dev teams, I think with that we will likely never see any such attacks.  Without a credible commitment, someone may eventually try it and hope to profit off a potential split.

author: jgm
content: Given that we are most likely to be in a world post-merge where validators sign blocks blind, that seems like a poorly aimed request.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why do you say that?

author: jgm
content:
Who do you believe would be carrying out censorship, and who would you punish for said censorship?

(Forgetting the question of how to prove censorship, but we'll gloss over that for now.)

author: sky.cactus
content: The validators that did the censorship (e.g., deep reorg, or refusing to build on top of blocks with certain transactions in them or signed by certain validators).

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are referring to the attackers being custodians (e.g., Coinbase) or delegates (Lido/Rocketpool), it doesn't matter.  Not your keys, not your coins.  If you delegate your decision making to someone else and they make a bad decision, you will suffer the financial consequences of it.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we don't uphold that, then Proof of Stake becomes radically less secure and (IMO) offers no tangible benefit over Proof of Work.

author: sky.cactus
content: The whole thing with Proof of Stake that makes it so powerful is that a user activated hard fork *can* retroactively punish bad actors for doing things that we cannot automatically catch.  This is unlike Proof of Work where once you execute the attack, you cannot be punished retroactively.

author: jgm
content:
Either of those situations would require a supermajority of them to be owned by the controlling entity.  Which is a more general problem than reorging the chain.

And that is both expensive and overcomplicated.  With MEV-boost a validator is given a hash of the transactions to sign, so has no idea if it is carrying out censorship or not (on a transaction level, anyway).  As long as a single builder is in control (and I think we agreed on this back on a post on ethresearch that this seems highly probably to be the case) then they can censor transactions at source, never appearing in a block, and can not only provide plausible deniability ("I didn't see it in the dark pool from which I built the blocks"; "there were always better transactions to include") but even if the community decided that they their denials rang hollow there would be no way to punish them, as they don't have any skin in the game.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah.  If someone tries to censor with PBS it only takes one non-PBS validator to prevent the censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: While I agree that there will likely be a dominant builder, I find it unlikely that no validator will defect from the strategy of "always accept blocks from the single dominant builder".

author: sky.cactus
content: So I am less worried about PBS censorship because any altruist can break the cycle, unlike majority validator censorship (only way to break the cycle is user activated slashing fork).

author: jgm
content: Although true in theory, a 1/400000 chance of being able to avoid the censorship every 12 seconds seems like practical censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: Sorry, when I say "one validator" I meant "one validating client" (possibly multiple validators).  Your point still generally stands though.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we have good ideas for in-protocol solutions to that which can likely be deployed prior to any single builder completely taking over.

author: potuz
content:
I do think this is likely the largest danger to Ethereum today: the likely dominance of a single builder. I think that instead of going into the merits of whether clients should  commit to punish censoring large entities (which, if I were in charge of making those commitments for a client I wouldn't) I think I would turn around the question and ask if clients would compromise on punishing a censoring builder. I think this is something where stock clients have a saying. I find it weird that clients are already supporting a client-relay-builder API when a skeleton of the relay-builder API was just released this weekend. There's an honest fear amongst clients that those that don't implement MEV-boost will be left aside. This is a reasonable fear and at the same one a dangerous one. I think if we are faced with the situation of a single censoring builder then clients will be faced with the option of either
1- leave things as they are
2- drop support for MEV-boost and accept their loss of share
3- become uncensoring builders themselves

author: killari.
content: forking the chain because someone is censoring is going to be really controversial

author: jgm
content:
I think that 2) and 3) are basically the same thing.

I argued in the past that having non-consensus, non-stake actors (builders) be a critical piece of the chain wasn't a great way to go, but the "untrusted validator/trusted builder" model took hold.  Realistically, it will take a community effort to counterbalance this (I don't think that a consensus-level solution is going to happen any time soon).

author: potuz
content: I agree with this except the very first sentence. I believe clients just simply wiping out their MEV-boost support will see their usage drop down to zero. As such they will be forced to come up with a viable alternative or accept the loss. And yes, I believe with you that a building monopoly is going to be the devil we'll have to fight soon. But on the other hand, I myself can't come up with a better solution than PBS+crList and hope for the best at the moment.

author: jgm
content: The fallback is to build blocks from the public mempool.  As that's all that a non-dominant builder is likely to have available in terms of transactions, if they walk away from MEV-boost they'll have to build their own blocks, no?

author: potuz
content: yeah, and that will mean loosing a big chunk of their use-base. Unless they become competitive builders themselves

author: potuz
content: which is 3

author: potuz
content: as opposed to 2

author: jgm
content:
I don't think that becoming a competitive builder is an option, because they won't have the transactions from which to build high-value blocks.

If a searcher finds a high-value MEV opportunity then I don't see them sending it to many builders. In fact, I suspect they won't want to send it to more than 1 because that massively increases the chance that the opportunity will be reverse-engineered.  So they'll only send it to the current largest builder as that gives them the highest % chance of their MEV being included in the next block.

Given this, I don't see an easy way of a strong second place builder existing, let alone others further down the list.

author: potuz
content: Here's the part that is to fight internally within teams, but if this is given as an option to counteract a monopolitic censoring builder, then teams have the leverage of actually doing 2+3 at the same time, leaving users with the option of switching clients and effectively saying that they want to censor to gain more MEV, or accept that for a short term they may get less until the market sees that 1 of (as of today 5) clients is not using transactions from the relay pool

author: potuz
content: I strongly suspect that both prysm and lighthouse today have this leverage to play against any censoring agent

author: tokey1475
content: this a really interesting thought.  MEV-funded protocol development.  Ethermine currently runs their own mev-relay and I imagine many searchers send their bundles to them as well as flashbots.   While I agree with jgm that searchers will be very hesitant to send their bundle to an unknown upstart relay, if each client team ran their own builder which was their clients default block-builder, searchers would essentially be forced to send to each clients relay.  I think the clients could also generally be trusted to run honest relays.  I would much rather see MEV revenue go to client teams than to third-party builders.   In practice I'm not sure how well this would work though, as flashbots (or another builder) could just fork prysm, etc.. as they currently do with geth to redirect to their own relay.

author: tokey1475
content: client teams have some leverage to be sure, but I think a lot of it will come down to community pressure as it did with the client diversity push

author: chris2_2_2
content: What’s currently missing from mev is cuthroat competition. If everyone does mev then eventually companies will figure out they can pay slightly extra to have everyone blacklist their competition. That’s when MEV becomes undesirable to the network.
